awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Continuous Manufacturing of Hetero-Nanostructures Enabled by Colloidal Atomic Layer Deposition
awd_abstract_narration:
Cadmium selenide nanoplatelets are attractive materials for next generation, energy efficient displays and solid-state lighting devices. The synthesis of high-quality nanoplatelets is a multi-step process that is difficult to study and scale up using conventional approaches. This award supports collaborative research to develop a continuous manufacturing strategy that consistently produces highly efficient nanoplatelets. The projected strategy utilizes a layer-by-layer growth process that enables cost-effective synthesis of the high-performance nanomaterials. The project contributes to fundamental knowledge of the nanoplatelet growth process, the requirements of flow synthesis methods, and determine nanoplatelet structure through photoluminescence-performance relationships. If successful, the research could reduce the energy consumption of displays and solid-state lighting devices produced by mid to large-scale U.S. companies, and thereby benefit the nation's prosperity, health, and security. This collaborative research project involves integration of several fields including colloidal synthesis, reaction and chemical engineering, and materials science. This grant trains graduate and undergraduate students in the continuous manufacture of advanced materials. Additionally, the multi-disciplinary nature of this project facilitates participation of women and underrepresented groups in research and greatly impacts engineering education through hands-on experiments for undergraduate students. Furthermore, the YouTube is used to disseminate the acquired advanced manufacturing knowledge to a broader audience.

The continuous flow manufacturing process based on the colloidal atomic layer deposition (ALD) technique for synthesis of high-quality nanoplatelets is highly modular and versatile. Continuous flow manufacturing has the potential to overcome the current limitations of the batch scale production of emissive nanomaterials. However, some key scientific questions need to be thoroughly explored to realize the continuous manufacturing of semiconductor nanoplatelets using the colloidal ALD process. This research project develops the fundamental knowledge required for each step of the layer-by-layer growth process for nanomaterial synthesis. The continuous flow synthesis process is capable of synthesizing and purifying colloidal nanoplatelet heterostructures using a linear sequence of multiple reactor modules. The nanoplatelets manufactured in continuous flow are composed of a graded alloy emissive layer and several passivating shell layers engineered for solid-state lighting and micro-display applications. Continuous flow reactor design, a library of novel synthesis precursors, and in-line liquid-liquid phase separation technique enable unprecedented process intensification in advanced manufacturing of colloidal nanoplatelets. The novel continuous manufacturing process utilizing intensified flow reactors paves the way for in-flow manufacturing of other colloidal nanocrystals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this collaborative project was to develop an innovative, continuous flow process for scalable nanomanufacturing of high-performing semiconductor heteronanostructures—materials crucial for advancing solid-state lighting and microdisplay technologies. These heteronanostructures possess unique optical properties, making them ideal for use in light-emitting diodes (LEDs) and other photonic devices.

Key Achievements:

1. We successfully designed a continuous flow reactor capable of scalable nanomanufacturing of high-quality colloidal heteronanostructures. The developed modular flow reactors integrated all synthesis steps, including the controlled layer-by-layer shell growth into a seamless process.

2. We created an autonomous microfluidic system called “AlphaFlow”, which utilized reinforcement learning and automated experimentation to autonomously discover and optimize multi-step synthetic routes of high-performing heteronanostructures without any human intervention. AlphaFlow performed reactions in 10-microliter droplets and continuously monitored the produced heteronanostructures using UV-Vis photoluminescence and absorption spectroscopy. Over 30 days of continuous autonomous operation, AlphaFlow autonomously discovered a novel multi-step synthesis route to produce high-performing colloidal heteronanostructures.

3. Using a novel single-droplet flow reactor, we studied the mass transport kinetics of colloidal atomic layer deposition (c-ALD) process. This knowledge allowed us to optimize the c-ALD process, resulting in heterostructures with improved optical properties and higher photoluminescence quantum yields.

The science and engineering knowledge generated in this collaborative project advanced the field of nanomaterial synthesis by introducing a fully automated, scalable method for producing high-quality colloidal heteronanostructures. The integration of machine learning, specifically reinforcement learning, into the multi-step colloidal synthesis process represents a significant innovation and research acceleration in colloidal nanoscience. The developed autonomous microfluidic platform allowed for rapid exploration and optimization of complex chemical spaces, leading to the discovery of new colloidal synthesis routes that might be overlooked by traditional methods.

By bridging the gap between laboratory research and commercial manufacturing, our continuous flow process paves the way for large-scale production of advanced nanomaterials, potentially reducing costs and accelerating product development cycles. The autonomous platform and methodologies we've developed can be applied to other multistep chemical syntheses, benefiting fields like pharmaceuticals, and specialty chemicals. Additionally, our open-source self-driving lab, AlphaFlow, provides a valuable tool for researchers and educators in chemical and materials sciences, promoting innovation and collaboration in the scientific community.

This project has demonstrated that combining continuous flow chemistry with machine learning-guided experimentation can revolutionize the way advanced nanomaterials are synthesized. By automating the discovery and production processes, we've not only improved the efficiency and scalability of heteronanostructure’s nanomanufacturing process but also opened new avenues for innovation across multiple scientific disciplines. Our findings hold promise for significant technological advancements that can benefit society through improved devices and sustainable manufacturing practices.


Last Modified: 10/18/2024
Modified by: Milad Abolhasani

Image
  • A self-driving lab for autonomous discovery and optimization of multi-step chemistry
    Amanda A. Volk

    AlphaFlow
